description: From Middle English oonly, onli, onlych, onelich, anely, from Old English ānlīċ, ǣnlīċ (“like; similar; equal”), from Proto-Germanic *ainalīkaz, equivalent to one +‎ -ly. Cognate with obsolete Dutch eenlijk, German ähnlich (“similar”), Old Norse álíkr, Swedish enlig (“unified”). Regarding the different phonological development of only and one, see the note in one.

examples: He is the only doctor for miles.
The only people in the stadium were the fans: no players, coaches, or officials.
He was the only male in attendance at the boyband concert.
That was the only time I went to Turkey.

entries.meaning: Without sibling; without a sibling of the same gender.
examples: He is their only son, in fact, an only child.

entries.meaning: Without others or anything further; exclusively.
examples: My heart is hers, and hers only.
The cat sat only on the mat. It kept off the sofa.
Only yesterday did I feed you with bread for your bodies; today I offer you the bread of life for your hungry souls.

entries.meaning: (Britain) Used to express surprise or consternation at an action.
examples: She's only gone and run off with the milkman!

entries.meaning: Introduces a disappointing or surprising outcome that renders futile something previously mentioned.
examples: They rallied from a three-goal deficit only to lose in the final two minutes of play.
I helped him out only for him to betray me.
The consistent finding  […]  that infants who are onlies do not differ from those who have siblings despite their lesser history of exposure to differential treatment is perplexing.
